data.text:
Itâs that time of year when American literature fans start to wonder not only whether any American is going to take home the Nobel Prize in Literature, but if Philip Roth will finally get the one major literary award â the biggest of all literary awards â that has eluded him all these years. Even though the odds arenât in his favor this year, a win for the retired Roth would shore up the claim that 7.7 out of 10 members of the âliteratiâ make: Philip Roth is the greatest living American writer.

But does it really matter whether most people think youâre the greatest of all writers from the United States? Thereâs no official title, no Hall of Greatest American Writers that ushers a new member into its ranks every few years, and no ceremony where they place a crown upon your head and proclaim that thereâs a new Greatest Living Writer. The idea of a greatest living writer is absurd, but the most important living American writer â thatâs a whole other conversation entirely. Itâs something very worth talking about, and thereâs no better time than the present, as we celebrate the 20th anniversary of the last American and first black woman to win the Nobel Prize in Literature: Toni Morrison. She should be recognized as the most important living American writer, and has been that since the day she gave this speech:

We shouldnât overvalue big literary prizes when it comes to deciding what constitutes greatness. There are plenty of extremely talented writers who havenât won any awards, and Iâd place their impact on literature alongside any Man Booker winner out there. Still, Morrison is the last American writer recognized by the people who hand out the medals for the most prestigious literary award in the world. In the eyes of the global literary community, Toni Morrison was the last American writer truly deserving of that honor.

âTis the season to celebrate Morrisonâs biggest achievement, so let us take time to reflect on an impressive body of work, which not only includes her classics like Beloved and Song of Solomon, but also impressive nonfiction that has left an undeniable mark on America. Because while we trump up the Roths of the world, Morrison has been both consistent and diverse with her work since the 1970s. A handful of us care enough to groan whenever Jonathan Franzen says something about social media, but when Toni Morrison says something about a president, itâs monumental. Morrison is, as John Freeman notes in the opening to his interview with her in the collection How to Read a Novelist, âa direct descendent of William Faulknerâs lyrical modernism.â Her books contain everything from elements of magical realism to moments of the dirty realism (a phrase coined by another writer related to Granta, Bill Buford) that has made writers like Cormac McCarthy a critical darling and Raymond Carver a god among writers.

Iâm not saying that Morrison hasnât achieved that status: people rave about her novels, they buy lots of them, her books get turned into films, college professors teach them, and most writers would probably give up a body part to learn to do what she does. Yet somehow it feels like, while Toni Morrison remains our most important living author, her 20-year-old Nobel win has left everything sheâs done since 1993 somewhat under-appreciated, as those anxious to place the Greatest Living Writer crown on a new head have become so preoccupied with wondering why certain writers havenât won an award that will finally validate their greatness once and for all.

So, as we sit here on the eve of another Nobel Prize announcement (whether it goes to an American or not should even matter, by the way), it is worth remembering that Toni Morrison has been the representative of all that is right with American literature for two decades. Rather than complaining about Philip Roth, weâd be better off celebrating by spending some overdue time revisiting her work.
